number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 8
Product received for free
												Mind Spheres is a puzzle game where you need to move a marble from one end of a track to another, by manipulating elements in the track to get the ball where it need to go.  I got it from a Indiegala giveaway, and have found it pretty fun so far, so I thought I'd throw in my two cents.First, this game is pretty casual.  Its music is very relaxing, and its puzzles are relatively easy compared to most Steam puzzle games (*coughEnglishCountryTunecough*).  Also, it doesn't have a lot of mechanics, though it does build on the few it has (This game takes the "less is more" approach to its mechanics, which is good).If you're looking for a tough challenge, you won't find one here.  If you're a puzzle game veteran who wants a long game to sink your teeth into, you also might not like this one; I tore through about half of the game's puzzles in around 20 minutes, and completed it in ~1 hour.  But if you want a relaxing puzzle game, or if it's your first time venturing into the puzzle game genre, Mind Spheres easy to recommend.This is a physics game, and the physics are relatively sound (I really don't understand why the game has a space background, as the puzzles are pretty grounded in gravity).  Three flaws, however: (1) I've had to restart a level multiple times because I put my platform JUST A PIXEL TOO HIGH and the marble got stuck on it (which is super frustrating.  This even happened because A PART OF THE LEVEL was sticking out and made my marble stop.  Really?!), (2) the lack of zoom in this game or any way to rotate the camera does not help, and (3) the triangle-bouncy-thing makes the marble bounce *way* too high, so it's nigh inpossible to see where it'll come down.  It's also a tad irritating that you have to restart the whole level when you make just one mistake, but then again the levels are so short, it's not too big a deal (not as big as it might be in other games, anyway).This game also chooses the "learn by doing" approach of teaching new mechanics: it just puts in new platforms in as you go, and lets you see what they do.  I think it works, mainly because the levels introducing them are short enough that you can just try again if something unexpected happens.  And I definitely prefer it over a boring tutorial.Mind Spheres also has Steam trading cards, so.  There's that, if you're a trading card fan like me.  It also has quite a few achievements, all which are unlocked naturally as you progress.All in all, this is a pretty neat game, a casual physics puzzler with some good fun to be had.  I'd totally recommend it if you want a light, relaxing experience.(Also, personally, I would LOVE a level editor to create and share my own puzzles--the simple mechanics and maps just begs for a level editor.  PLEASE, Microblast Games?)

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 12
												Right so here is the thing. I DID enjoy this game. Don't get me wrong, it isn't anything majorly exciting or anything like that. It's just a nice casual little game with some not too strenuous puzzles. You can blaze through most of the puzzles in a single try bar a couple of them which honestly were more annoying than fun. Which can be seen as a flaw actually, some of the puzzles just being too annoying to want to do. The visuals weren't painful to look at and the music was relatively interesting, all in all what you want if you just want a small game to unwind with. That being said...it did have some issues.So here are the major cons.Despite my RAM being plentiful for this game it would constantly crash not only the game (coming up with some total BS system memory low message) but on some occasions the whole computer, forcing a restart to be done. This is made even more frustrating given I haven't played it for much time at all and yet it happened multiple times.Second, for some questionable reason on the screen where you manipulate objects on many occasions the screen would go completely white. It would revert upon hitting space to get the ball rolling but...well what's the point if the white screen stops me being able to move stuff around? I did manage to win a couple of levels with that though (which reinforces just how easy some of the puzzles were if you don't even have to change anything). But even so the only way I could stop that happening was quitting and restarting the game...and then hoping I could go through as many levels as possible before it happened again.Third. Now this was also really annoying. There were times when the game would just randomly decide you had failed a mission at random intervals and bring up the "restart?" screen. The ball was still moving and actually hadn't even come close to stopping on many occasions that this happened on. Once my ball was in mid air coming down onto the end goal and it just randomly decided I had failed and blurred out the screen. Now I probably don't have to explain how f'ing annoying THAT was.So while I liked it and I do recommend it if anyone is just looking for a bit of relaxating gameplay...I would definitely like to advise the developer to look into these issues because it did get to the point where I was about to quit and uninstall the game. So if you (developer person) can have a little look into some of these matters to make the game better for everyone, I'm sure it would be appreciated.

content:
Posted: July 31, 2016
												This is a quick and easy puzzle game that you can do a little bit of and feel great. The puzzles are fairly simple and straight forward, but it's a fun exercise while waiting for something to install or just a moment of down time. The rotation of background and 3D objects might not be OK for everyone. Right now "Great Schematics" level 6, the 36th puzzle has a design flaw that traps the ball in a loop of up-the-ramp behavior because the bounce at the bottom of the ramp isn't strong enough. Neither peice is movable, but up to this point it was nice to spend 10 minutes here or there playing.  Because I cannot skip a puzzle, the rest of the game is locked. It came in a bundle, so no real loss, but it would have been great to have gone forwrad.Overall the game was nice and the kids enjoy the challenge themselves.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 10
Product received for free
												Fifty minutes is what it took me to finish it.I got it for free but I would buy it because it has potential. Okay so, the problem of this game is, or rather the two problems are:1. It's too easy- From start to finish this game shows no challenge. Even the slightest progression would improve the overall feeling drastically2. There is no support for custom levels- Even with the "too easy levels" that came with the game, user base would be able to create awesome content with this game. In general, I liked the art, the background music ("Relaxing The Sims kind of music"), I even loved the simplicity of it. Minimalistic and yet so elegant. Menus look great too.Gameplay is rather simple, with a couple of different objects that ball can interact with, but as I said, even with this limited toolkit, this game needed some feeling of progression. More challenges. Maybe allow us to move the interactable pieces? Make levels harder as we move on, opposed to just adding new pieces with different behaviours while keeping the same old "tweak a bit to solve" mentality. Some 40+ levels were easier than the first few levels ... I think that this game can be something awesome with mod support and some tweaks.

Product received for free
												Completed the entire game in 61 minutes. Puzzles not so challenging, with some luck and 'trial and error' involved. In some puzzles, some pieces don't even serve a purpose and can be completely ignored. Even if you don't fine tune the pieces the ball can still reach its destination with a bit of luck. Game lags after some time in, and consumes too much RAM. I had 5 out of 8 GB of RAM filled and the game stopped working, and I got a warning from Windows that I have to close the program. I had to restart it one more time before the warning came up again because it was lagging. This issue needs to be fixed. Music is good and relaxing. I got it for free, so I give it a 6/10. If you're looking for a short, relaxing and relatively easy puzzle game, get it on a sale.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 17
Mind Spheres is a relaxing puzzle game where the player is tasked with manipulating the level in order to allow a marble to navigate itself to the end goal. There are a number of different platforms that can alter the path the marble will take and that bounce the marble around obstacles. I found that most of the levels were quite easy to beat, where most can be completed with only one try. I really appreciate that restarting the level also does not reset the placement of its obstacles.As for what I don't like: there's a severe lack of information when I'm met with new mechanics. Each platform is basically the same shape and size, the only way to differentiate them is by their colour (other than some pyramid looking things that behave the same way as the basic platforms, I don't know why they exist other than to confuse). There's no visual indication for what each platform does so it's often impossible to know how to plan a level before trialling it. I also feel that the soundtrack, which mostly comprises of a softly played piano, does not fit the tone or theme of the game.There are a number of issues in Mind Spheres regarding the overly sensitive rotation of platforms. There's a random "sorry" fail-state that pops up for no discernible reason even when my marble is still in motion. I have also discovered an unintended bug where holding the mouse down to rotate platforms will also begin to rotate any other platform if I continue to drag the cursor over them, it really should be locked to a single platform at a time as this can quickly ruin the layout of a course.Mind Spheres is a simple game with minimal visuals. It's a decent time waster, best played while watching television.

content:
Posted: April 9
												(Key received for free from Indiegala.  Thanks, bros!)Dev claims that Mind Spheres is like Golf and Pinball.  I feel it's more like a Rube Goldberg machine that wants you to tinker with bits and pieces of it until you find a solution to each puzzle.  Simply modify each platform until you are finished redirecting the ball into the pedestal.Aside from that, there's not much to know about Mind Spheres.  It's priced at $2, but is $0.50 when it goes on sale.   Grab it when it's about $0.10-$0.50 if you want a quick, easy game that you can finish in an hour.  It also has card drops, so you'll get a slight refund from your purchase.   Although I think this game's really fun, the replayability is a bit low and the price tag also betrays how much you'll get in return.6/10  A nice, casual experience about guiding a ball into a hole.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 8, 2016
												Mind Spheres is a cool concept and very decent for the price. It reminds me of one of my favorite physics puzzlers Enigmo. However I ran into some issues with the game during play that make it diffifult/cumbersome.For starters I am playing this on mac and starting around level 9 periodically the screen would go completely white and I couldn't see the puzzle anymore. You could click spacebar to initiate the sequence but then hitting R to reload would make the screen go white again. The only solution I found was to restart the game entirely.Secondly, the game the board each time you attempt the puzzle so you can't make small tweaks to execute the puzzle correct. You have to start from scratch each time.Last point - given there are multiple ways to solve the puzzle it would be fun to have a timer to show how fast you were able to solve the puzzle. Alternatively, achievements could be awarded for taking the most round-a-bout way.I really like this genre of games but I think it may require a couple of tweaks before recommending to a friend. Please keep making games like this though!---EDIT---After reviewing all of the updates that the developer has made, I would recommend this game to a frieend. I really like having the 'saved states' so that you do not need to recreate your work all the time and I have not experienced the white screen crashing as noted before. I still wouldn't mind seeing a timer and challenges eventually added but great work on the updates! Thanks.

												Took me 67 minutes to beat this game, but ya know what? At $0.49 it was cheaper than most arcade games.This was a pretty fun puzzle/physics game; it did keep my attention enough to beat it over two play sessions. My only complaint is that the game is too easy and doesn't reach its full potential. I was only challenge on the last few levels and even then, it was more of a game of getting the physics to work and less of a puzzle game. The game could use more levels with alternative ways to win. Also, free DLC with some bloody hard maps would be nice!!At $0.49 on sale or $2 regular price, you're still going to get your moneys worth.

content:
Posted: April 8
Product received for free
												Mind Spheres is a good time, for its asking price. It's a very forgiving physics puzzle game. Also extremely easy. Take it from someone who's usually not very good at these. If you've ever played anything out of the Crazy Machines series, you'll feel right at home here. There's a ball that needs to get to its location, and you have to make a path for it.Thing is, all the pieces are already set in place, and all you do is just move them around. The engine also got buggy at times, and the wonky physics can sometimes work in your favor, allowing you a degree of flexibility (or luck) as you complete some levels clearly not in the way it was intended. There are no other game modes besides the campaign and the 50 puzzles, so replayability is out of the window.It only took me an hour to beat everything, but for the short time it gave me, it was enjoyable. At least it's cheap.

												I bought this game on sale last weekend for about 49 cents. I got the chance to try it out today and I must say it is a very nice game with about 50 puzzle levels or so. It begins as easy, in my opinion. You can learn very quickly the mechanics on the game which are simple and effective. For me the game is quite easy, only challenging part was the Eternal Loops (last part). The soundtrack for me is quite nice as well, very well done on the piano playing. I can't really find any negative aspect on the gameAll in all, I give this game 10/10 taking in consideration the following aspects:-Challenge-Price-Achievements-Steam trade cards-FunI recommend it to everyone who is trying to relax and play a nice little game for about an hour in order to complete it paying just the price of a beer.
